s.text: Krens, a motorcycle enthusiast and the owner of two BMWs, contributes an utterly unpersuasive introduction to the catalog, in which he breezily declares that the distinction between the unique work of art and the mechanically produced object is now "irrelevant."

Krens, a motorcycle enthusiast and the owner of two BMWs, contributes an utterly unpersuasive introduction to the catalog, in which he breezily declares that the distinction between the unique work of art and the mechanically produced object is now "irrelevant."
His tenure began with a splashy exhibition on royal patronage and built to the crescendo of "King Tut," which visitors waited in long lines to see in 1977.
But despite his excesses, Hoving was still in some sense a conventional-minded curator.
But despite his excesses, Hoving was still in some sense a conventional-minded curator.
But despite his excesses, Hoving was still in some sense a conventional-minded curator.
But despite his excesses, Hoving was still in some sense a conventional-minded curator.
But despite his excesses, Hoving was still in some sense a conventional-minded curator.

Conservative critics such as Jed Perl and Hilton Kramer, who predictably have decried the motorcycle exhibit, might reflect upon the fact that the populist approach it represents grew out of the Mapplethorpe-National Endowment for the Arts controversy of the late 1980s--which they started.
But that doesn't excuse the way some directors have responded to these pressures: with a style of populism that is very different from a genuine democratic sensibility.
In an entertaining book published a few years ago, Making the Mummies Dance: Inside the Metropolitan Museum of Art , Hoving unabashedly recounts his own Machiavellian management and P.T.
